| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | [monst.c#line844](/wiki/Monst.c#line844 "Monst.c") |

A **cave spider**, s, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a tiny [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") and [oviparous](/wiki/Oviparous "Oviparous") [spider](/wiki/Spider "Spider") that is the most basic monster of the [arachnid or centipede](/wiki/Arachnid_or_centipede "Arachnid or centipede") monster class. Cave spiders can move freely across [webs](/wiki/Web "Web"), and can [hide](/wiki/Hide "Hide") under items to catch [you](/wiki/You "You") by surprise.

A cave spider has a single bite attack, and possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

Eating a cave spider [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 1⁄14 chance of conveying poison resistance.

A character [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a cave spider can spin a web on their square using the #[monster](/wiki/Monster_\(command\) "Monster (command)") [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Cave spiders will randomly spin webs as they move - this random chance is based on the number of surrounding walls, making a spider more likely to spin a web in enclosed spaces.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 dNethack](#dNethack)
  - [5.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.4 notdNetHack](#notdNetHack)
  - [5.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated cave spiders are always created hostile, and often appear in small [groups](/wiki/Groups "Groups"). A cave spider can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a [giant spider](/wiki/Giant_spider "Giant spider"), and can hatch from cave spider and giant spider [eggs](/wiki/Egg "Egg").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Cave spiders appear among the random s that are part of the first [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster class for [Tourists](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Tourist quest](/wiki/Tourist_quest "Tourist quest"). They also appear among the random s that are part of the second quest monster class for [Rangers](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger") and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Ranger quest](/wiki/Ranger_quest "Ranger quest").

Cave spiders generated at level creation are given a random item to hide under.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Strategy

While cave spiders are not particularly dangerous as the first hiding monsters a character will likely encounter, they can move at the same [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") as an unhasted character, and their 3 [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") can make hitting them slightly difficult. Due to the spider's hiding habits, a [thrown](/wiki/Thrown "Thrown") projectile causes them to "stick" in place often, allowing you to freely pick them off or even escape if the situation warrants it. This can also be put to use in some [treasure zoos](/wiki/Treasure_zoo "Treasure zoo"), where a hiding cave spider can block the door and hem in the other monsters; you can then attack them from range at your leisure, e.g. with a [polearm](/wiki/Polearm "Polearm") or [lance](/wiki/Lance "Lance").

## History

The cave spider first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Cave spider](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cave_spider "wikipedia:Cave spider")***

The name "cave spider" can refer to any number of underground or cavern-dwelling species of spider, with one of the most commonly known species being the European cave spider (*Meta menardi*), which is a long-jawed [orb-weaver spider](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orb-weaver_spider "wikipedia:Orb-weaver spider"). Various types of spiders are also frequently depicted as inhabiting caves in several forms of cultural folklore and other works of fiction, whether they are normally cave-dwellers or otherwise.

European cave spiders have a natural range extending from Scandinavia to North Africa, and from Europe to Korea; there are also transplanted populations as far apart as Japan and Madagascar. Adult cave spiders are photophobic and live in places free from light such as caves, mines and various tunnels, and emerge around dusk to hunt. After mating, female cave spiders produce drop-shaped egg sacs that usually hang from the roof of the habitat by a silk thread near the entrance - the cave spiderlings feed on the yolk of their egg sac until the first molt, and then exit the cave to disperse via ballooning. Spiderlings are strongly attracted to light unlike adult cave spiders, which may be an evolutionary adaptation.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [werespiders](/wiki/Werespider "Werespider") can summon cave spiders by calling for help.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

[The Spider Caves](/wiki/The_Spider_Caves "The Spider Caves") generates several giant spider eggs on level creation that will generate cave spiders if allowed to hatch.

### dNethack

In [dNethack](/wiki/DNethack "DNethack"), [drow](/wiki/Drow_\(starting_race\) "Drow (starting race)") of all roles (except for [Noblewomen](/wiki/Noble "Noble")) will start the game with a tame cave spider.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), cave spiders will occasionally spin webs while moving, with web-spinning being more likely in enclosed spaces.

### notdNetHack

In [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), in addition to dNetHack details, [Chupoclops](/wiki/Chupoclops "Chupoclops") is generated with several cave spider eggs when summoned by an [Illithanachronounbinder](/wiki/Illithanachronounbinder "Illithanachronounbinder").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), cave spiders also spin webs while moving, with webs being more likely in enclosed spaces. Cave spiders grow up into [large spiders](/index.php?title=Large_spider\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Large spider (page does not exist)"), which can grow up into giant spiders.

Drow are capable of taming cave spiders and other spiders as [domestic animals](/wiki/Domestic_animal "Domestic animal").

## Encyclopedia entry

- *See the [encyclopedia entry for spider](/wiki/Spider#Encyclopedia_entry "Spider").*

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mondata.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 970](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mondata.c#L970)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1243](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L1243): *spiders and the like get a free house*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [were.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 154](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/were.c#line154 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/were.c")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Attacks

Bite 1d2

Base level 1
Base experience 8
Speed 12
Base AC 3
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 50
Nutritional value 50
Size Tiny
Resistances Poison
Resistances conveyed Poison (7%)

A cave spider:

  • can hide under items.
  • has no hands.
  • is an animal.
  • can lay eggs.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • normally appears in small groups.
Reference monst.c#line844

A cave spider, s, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is a tiny carnivorous and oviparous spider that is the most basic monster of the arachnid or centipede monster class. Cave spiders can move freely across webs, and can hide under items to catch you by surprise.

A cave spider has a single bite attack, and possesses poison resistance.

Eating a cave spider corpse or tin has a 1⁄14 chance of conveying poison resistance.

A character polymorphed into a cave spider can spin a web on their square using the #monster extended command.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Cave spiders will randomly spin webs as they move - this random chance is based on the number of surrounding walls, making a spider more likely to spin a web in enclosed spaces.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
    • 5.2 dNethack
    • 5.3 xNetHack
    • 5.4 notdNetHack
    • 5.5 EvilHack
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Randomly generated cave spiders are always created hostile, and often appear in small groups. A cave spider can grow up into a giant spider, and can hatch from cave spider and giant spider eggs.[1]

Cave spiders appear among the random s that are part of the first quest monster class for Tourists and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Tourist quest. They also appear among the random s that are part of the second quest monster class for Rangers and make up 6⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Ranger quest.

Cave spiders generated at level creation are given a random item to hide under.[2]

Strategy

While cave spiders are not particularly dangerous as the first hiding monsters a character will likely encounter, they can move at the same speed as an unhasted character, and their 3 AC can make hitting them slightly difficult. Due to the spider's hiding habits, a thrown projectile causes them to "stick" in place often, allowing you to freely pick them off or even escape if the situation warrants it. This can also be put to use in some treasure zoos, where a hiding cave spider can block the door and hem in the other monsters; you can then attack them from range at your leisure, e.g. with a polearm or lance.

History

The cave spider first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Cave spider

The name "cave spider" can refer to any number of underground or cavern-dwelling species of spider, with one of the most commonly known species being the European cave spider (Meta menardi), which is a long-jawed orb-weaver spider. Various types of spiders are also frequently depicted as inhabiting caves in several forms of cultural folklore and other works of fiction, whether they are normally cave-dwellers or otherwise.

European cave spiders have a natural range extending from Scandinavia to North Africa, and from Europe to Korea; there are also transplanted populations as far apart as Japan and Madagascar. Adult cave spiders are photophobic and live in places free from light such as caves, mines and various tunnels, and emerge around dusk to hunt. After mating, female cave spiders produce drop-shaped egg sacs that usually hang from the roof of the habitat by a silk thread near the entrance - the cave spiderlings feed on the yolk of their egg sac until the first molt, and then exit the cave to disperse via ballooning. Spiderlings are strongly attracted to light unlike adult cave spiders, which may be an evolutionary adaptation.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, werespiders can summon cave spiders by calling for help.[3]

The Spider Caves generates several giant spider eggs on level creation that will generate cave spiders if allowed to hatch.

dNethack

In dNethack, drow of all roles (except for Noblewomen) will start the game with a tame cave spider.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, cave spiders will occasionally spin webs while moving, with web-spinning being more likely in enclosed spaces.

notdNetHack

In notdNetHack, in addition to dNetHack details, Chupoclops is generated with several cave spider eggs when summoned by an Illithanachronounbinder.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, cave spiders also spin webs while moving, with webs being more likely in enclosed spaces. Cave spiders grow up into large spiders, which can grow up into giant spiders.

Drow are capable of taming cave spiders and other spiders as domestic animals.

Encyclopedia entry

See the encyclopedia entry for spider.

References

  1. ↑ src/mondata.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 970
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1243: spiders and the like get a free house
  3. ↑ were.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 154

A '''cave spider''', {{monsym|cave spider}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a tiny [[carnivorous]] and [[oviparous]] [[spider]] that is the most basic monster of the [[arachnid or centipede]] monster class. Cave spiders can move freely across [[web]]s, and can [[hide]] under items to catch [[you]] by surprise.

A cave spider has a single bite attack, and possesses [[poison resistance]].

Eating a cave spider [[corpse]] or [[tin]] has a {{frac|14}} chance of conveying poison resistance.

A character [[polymorph]]ed into a cave spider can spin a web on their square using the #[[Monster (command)|monster]] [[extended command]].

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Cave spiders will randomly spin webs as they move - this random chance is based on the number of surrounding walls, making a spider more likely to spin a web in enclosed spaces.}}

==Generation==
Randomly generated cave spiders are always created hostile, and often appear in small [[groups]]. A cave spider can [[grow up]] into a [[giant spider]], and can hatch from cave spider and giant spider [[egg]]s.{{refsrc|src/mondata.c|970|nethack=3.6.7}}

Cave spiders appear among the random {{white|s}} that are part of the first [[quest]] monster class for [[Tourist]]s and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Tourist quest]]. They also appear among the random {{white|s}} that are part of the second quest monster class for [[Ranger]]s and make up {{frac|6|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Ranger quest]]. 

Cave spiders generated at level creation are given a random item to hide under.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1243|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=spiders and the like get a free house}}

==Strategy==
While cave spiders are not particularly dangerous as the first hiding monsters a character will likely encounter, they can move at the same [[speed]] as an unhasted character, and their 3 [[AC]] can make hitting them slightly difficult. Due to the spider's hiding habits, a [[thrown]] projectile causes them to "stick" in place often, allowing you to freely pick them off or even escape if the situation warrants it. This can also be put to use in some [[treasure zoo]]s, where a hiding cave spider can block the door and hem in the other monsters; you can then attack them from range at your leisure, e.g. with a [[polearm]] or [[lance]].

==History==
The cave spider first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Cave spider}}
The name "cave spider" can refer to any number of underground or cavern-dwelling species of spider, with one of the most commonly known species being the European cave spider (''Meta menardi''), which is a long-jawed [[Wikipedia:Orb-weaver spider|orb-weaver spider]]. Various types of spiders are also frequently depicted as inhabiting caves in several forms of cultural folklore and other works of fiction, whether they are normally cave-dwellers or otherwise.

European cave spiders have a natural range extending from Scandinavia to North Africa, and from Europe to Korea; there are also transplanted populations as far apart as Japan and Madagascar. Adult cave spiders are photophobic and live in places free from light such as caves, mines and various tunnels, and emerge around dusk to hunt. After mating, female cave spiders produce drop-shaped egg sacs that usually hang from the roof of the habitat by a silk thread near the entrance - the cave spiderlings feed on the yolk of their egg sac until the first molt, and then exit the cave to disperse via ballooning. Spiderlings are strongly attracted to light unlike adult cave spiders, which may be an evolutionary adaptation.

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], [[werespider]]s can summon cave spiders by calling for help.{{refsrc|were.c|154|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

[[The Spider Caves]] generates several giant spider eggs on level creation that will generate cave spiders if allowed to hatch.

===dNethack===
In [[dNethack]], [[Drow (starting race)|drow]] of all roles (except for [[Noble]]women) will start the game with a tame cave spider.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], cave spiders will occasionally spin webs while moving, with web-spinning being more likely in enclosed spaces.

===notdNetHack===
In [[notdNetHack]], in addition to dNetHack details, [[Chupoclops]] is generated with several cave spider eggs when summoned by an [[Illithanachronounbinder]].

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], cave spiders also spin webs while moving, with webs being more likely in enclosed spaces. Cave spiders grow up into [[large spider]]s, which can grow up into giant spiders.

Drow are capable of taming cave spiders and other spiders as [[domestic animal]]s.
